entry.title: Configuring Standard API in S/4 HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Generating OData of standard API :

First we have to login to SAP business accelerator hub account and go to SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public edition.

Choose a standard API as shown below

 

In this case I have choose the product master standard API.

Select the overview tab, under that we can see Communication Scenario ID.

 

Copy communication scenario from standard API. Now Move to the

 S/4Hana cloud system -> Communication Arrangements

 

Select the Option New, and add a Scenario ID which we have copied from the Standard API

 

 

 

 

 

Create new communication system:

Search for Communication System in S/4 HANA cloud, here we need to create user and password for all OData services

 

Click on New, 

 

System will ask for new communication system id and system name. we can give the ID & Name of our choice. And Click on create. 

 

Give the Host name as shown below,  

 

In User for Inbound Communication, click on Add and Create New Inbound Communication User. Click on “New User” 

 

Give the username and description and select on proposed password to get the password which will give by system itself. (Copy the user name and password and paste somewhere so that, Once the user and password has created we can use the same for all the OData service Consumption.) 

Click on create 

 

Click on Save  

 

Then add your custom communication system in this communication arrangement

 

Then you get required ODATA URL

 

Now will connect S/4HANA Cloud to Power BI or any other reporting tools through OData Feed. Example:Open Power BI->get Data->OData feed.

 

In the OData feed enter the OData URL generated in S/4HANA Cloud. And give user name and password that we have generated in S4hana cloud “Communication System” to get the OData url.

Then Click on connect.

 

Select the checkbox to data preview and click on Transform data or Load.

entry.title: SAP Collaborative ERP update for 2408. Share as cards, tab, or chat.
entry.content:
Our collaboration features are gaining popularity among SAP S/4HANA Cloud customers. Now, we have added a new capability to share content from an SAP Fiori elements app as an adaptive card through Microsoft Teams. This is available in the 2408 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. This update improves collaboration with your co-workers by providing another option to interact with a single source of data in your SAP S/4HANA system. You can now share application data with your colleagues as a card, tab, or chat.

Share as Card makes SAP S/4HANA data more portable

For SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers, a new "Share as Card" option is now available in the Microsoft Teams share menu.

This feature allows you to work directly within Microsoft Teams and execute actions right from your Teams environment.

The adaptive card in Microsoft Teams lets you perform simple tasks that will update your SAP S/4HANA Cloud data seamlessly.

Chat directly from the SAP app

In addition, when using SAP Fiori elements applications, you can now start a chat, video call, or voice call with your co-worker directly from within the app. This feature facilitates real-time communication for discussing issues or seeking clarification.

Actions come to you as To Do notifications

For early adopters a new Notifications feature is enabled in Microsoft Teams.

Receive notifications for tasks that are in your My Home page in SAP S/4HANA Cloud directly in your Microsoft Teams Activity Feed, enabling you to quickly begin working on tasks right from Teams.

Lots of great collaboration in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2408

What’s new in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2408?

  • Share as Card generally available
  • Contacts generally available
  • To Do’s in early adopter care

What’s next

We are continuing to enhance the integrations between SAP S/4HANA Cloud and Microsoft Teams. As was announced at SAP Sapphire, we will include new integrations between SAP Joule and Microsoft CoPilot. This will provide even more opportunities for collaboration between human experts when AI doesn’t have all the answers.

We’re looking forward to your feedback!

entry.title: Automatic Credit Score Calculation in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
1. Credit Management

In SAP, credit management is a function within Financial Supply Chain Management (FSCM) that oversees and regulates customer credit limits to promote timely payments and minimize the risk of bad debt. Mainly these 3 scope items are responsible for Overall credit management function:

Basic Credit Management (BD6)

Advanced Credit Management (1QM)

Credit Agency Integration (1RY)

2. Automatic Credit Score Calculation

Automatic Credit Score Calculation is a feature of advanced credit management that streamlines the process of setting credit scores through automation. We will explore how the system is set up and operates to automatically determine credit score.

Please note: This blog is intended for individuals who already have a fundamental understanding of basic credit management. Automatic Credit score Calculation is part of 1QM scope item.

There will be a separate blog for Automatic Credit Limit Calculation.

3. Related Configuration

Some configurations are managed through the configuration node (CBC or Manage Your Solution), while others are defined directly via various SAP Fiori Apps.

 

Process Step

App Name/ Config

Remarks

Credit Formula for Score and CL

Define Formulas [CBC]

Just the structure, values are filled with Fiori App

Rule for Scoring and Credit Limit, Rating procedure assignment

Create Rule for Scoring and Credit Limit Calculation [CBC]

 

Formula Parameters are created

Maintain Formula Parameters (App)

Formula Parameters are created and assigned to score formula group and limit formula

Formula is created

Manage Formula in Credit Management (App)

Formula is created (code is used previous one).
Simulation can be done

Valuation is assigned against the rules

Manage Credit Management Rules (app)

 

Credit Details are updated in Customer Master

Manage Credit Account

 

  • Define Formulas (CBC)

Here, we are only setting up the code and framework for the Credit Score Formula. The logic will be incorporated later in the Manage Formula in Credit Management App. This same formula is assigned during the configuration process in the "Create Rule for Scoring and Credit Limit Calculation" section.

  • Define Rating Procedure (CBC)

It is an optional configuration if you an agency which cannot find then you can create your own here.

You also need to define the rating results within your rating procedure, similar to how an agency assigns ratings like A, AA, AAA, B, etc or just A, B, C, D, E, etc.

In this blog, we've used the standard rating procedure, 'creditsafe,' for calculating credit scores.

 

  • Create Rule for Scoring and Credit Limit Calculation (CBC)

 

Here, we create a rule which is used for credit score and Credit Limit calculation. The formula is assigned to a rule within both the Score folder and the Credit Limit folder. We will focus Credit score folder in this blog.

Credit Score Folder:

Here, we assign credit score formula that we had created under ‘Define Formulas’

The rating procedure is like credit agencies, and several such agencies are available in the standard system. You also have the option to create custom rating procedures and assign them to rules for determining credit score.

Note: This Credit Score Rule is assigned with Business Partner (Customer) in Manage Credit Account App. Please refrain from using the Maintain Business Partner App for credit management purposes. It is recommended to use the Manage Credit Account App instead. Using the Maintain Business Partner App may not yield the desired outcomes in some processes within Credit Management.

 

  • Manage Formula in Credit Management (App)

You can create Credit Score Formula from Template or from scratch (create). We will create from scratch.

It is assigned to the formula you previously created in the configuration step "Define Formula."

Threshold and Rounding are applicable to credit limit calculations and will be explained in detail in another blog.

Scoring Formula Tab:

Multiple methods can be defined for calculating your credit score formula. In our approach, we have considered the following factors:

COUNTRY_REGION, CREDIT_GROUP, COFACE_RATING, CREDITSAFE_RATING, and CASH_RATIO

When assigning weight, there are two sections: Parameter Group (General, External Information) and Formula Parameter (COUNTRY_REGION, CREDIT_GROUP, CREDITSAFE_RATING and CASH_RATIO), each requiring specific weight allocation. You must ensure that the total for each individual group sums to 100, and then the overall parameter group weight also totals 100, as shown in the screenshot above.

 

Penalty Parameter

The penalty parameter is used to apply negative adjustments, such as deducting points, to address minor fraud or other issues in the overall credit score calculation. However, if the fraud is significant, you may opt to stop extending credit to that customer. In such cases, the Exit parameter can be used to set a zero or minimal credit limit, as explained in the next point.

 

Exit Parameter

The Exit parameter is typically used in cases of bankruptcy, major fraud, or similar situations where you would no longer extend credit to the customer. The Exit parameter sets a fixed credit score for the customer, ranging from 1 to 100, regardless of the system's calculated score.

This fixed score overrides the calculated score and becomes the final value assigned to the customer. Consequently, this will indirectly affect the credit limit calculation if you are using risk classes. Risk classes can be automated based on the score assigned to customers, and these risk classes can then be used in automatic determination of credit limit.

The calculation and logic for score calculation can be seen in the simulation in the blog below.

We have used the following Formula Parameters in our Credit Score Formula, which we will explore in detail in the subsequent step:

  1. Country/Region)
  2. Credit Group
  3. Coface Rating
  4. Creditsafe Rating
  5. Affidavit
  6. Fraud
  7. Bankruptcy

 

Credit Limit Simulation:

We can simulate the credit score calculation for a specific business partner to verify the functionality of our formula. You can expect the same results when performing calculations for the same customer in the Manage Credit Account App.

The system initially calculated the score as 64 (22+28+14) and applied a penalty of -40 points (10+30). However, due to the Exit formula parameter (i.e., Bankruptcy), the system overwrote the score to 1, which became the customer's final assigned score.

You can see the calculation for each parameter according to its assigned weight, including any negative adjustments for the penalty parameter. Additionally, the exit condition (parameter) can be observed, with its assigned rating overriding the overall calculation. Ultimately, the score assigned to the customer will be the one set in the exit parameter, such as 1.

 

  • Maintain Formula Parameters App

Numerous formula parameters are already available; ideally, you should use the standard ones, but it is also possible to create your own formula parameters in case business need.

Formula parameters can be categorized into two types:

  1. Formula Parameter for Score Calculation: Assigned to the Parameter Group for Score Formula (used in credit score formulas).
  2. Formula Parameter for Credit Limit Calculation: Assigned to the Parameter Group for Limit Formula (used in credit limit formulas).

In this blog, we will focus solely on the 'Parameter Category for Score Formula'.

Let's explore the specifics of below Formula Parameters which we have used in our Score Formula

  1. Country/Region
  2. Credit Group
  3. Coface Rating
  4. Creditsafe Rating
  5. Cash Ratio
  6. Affidavit
  7. Fraud
  8. Bankruptcy

If you create a custom Formula Parameter, it must be assigned to the appropriate folder where it belongs. In this blog, we have not created any custom formula parameters for score calculation, as the standard ones are sufficient.

 

COUNTRY_REGION (Country/Region)

 

CREDIT_GROUP (Credit Group)

CREDITSAFE_RATING (Creditsafe Rating)

Similarly, we can see other formula parameter.

  • Manage Credit Management Rules

Here, valuation is mapped to specific rules.

We will explore the rules that are pertinent to the Credit Score Formula:

  1. Formula: Parameter Evaluation
  2. General: Country/Region Risk

  

  • Formula: Parameter Evaluation

Assign values to the parameters that you use to calculate the scoring in credit management.

Pre-delivered formula parameters are available. You can define more formula parameters in this app: Maintain Formula Parameters 

 

We maintain several necessary formula parameters here for our credit score calculation. We assign variable values to these formula parameters, such as the credit group (whatever group you have created in the standard). For each credit group, you can specify an internal result (weightage/valuation). The internal result maintained here corresponds to the weightage you provided for the same formula parameter in the "Manage Formula in Credit Management" app. And that is how it works and contribute to credit score calculation.

There are six columns in Formula: Parameter Evaluation, each serving a different purpose:

  1. Formula Parameter
  2. Parameter Value
  3. Number (Parameter Value)
  4. Amount (Parameter Value)
  5. Date (Parameter Value)
  6. Interim Result

For each Formula Parameter, only one of the following columns will be populated—Parameter Value, Number (Parameter Value), Amount (Parameter Value), or Date (Parameter Value)—depending on the nature of the data, as indicated by the column names.

 

  • General: Country/Region Risk

Specify which country or region is associated with which country/region risk. This rule can be utilized for scoring in credit management. The corresponding country/region risk for each business partner is also displayed in the Manage Credit Accounts app.

 4. Master Data and Calculation Process in Manage Credit Account App

Assignment of Calculation Rule and Credit Check Rule

 

Credit scores are calculated at the business partner level, while credit limits are determined at the segment level. In this discussion, we'll focus on how Credit Score and Risk Class are determined. For information on credit limit calculation, stay tuned for an upcoming blog.

Note: The Calculation Rule (ZCRLIMIT) that we created in Create Rule for Scoring and Credit Limit Calculation configuration serves as the connection among all the configurations and settings implemented for calculating the credit score.

Maintenance of Fraud, Affidavit and Bankruptcy:

Imp: This data is assigned with X (not 1, 2, 3) under Parameter value in Maintain Credit Management Rules App

Financial Statement Data E.g. Cash Ratio

An import feature is available and should be used to update the customer's financial statement data.

 

  • Credit Score calculation.

The validity (score valid to) is determined by the configuration settings in the "Create Rule for Scoring and Credit Limit Calculation" configuration.

In the top right corner, there is a "Calculate Score" button, which becomes available in the Scoring Tab when in edit mode. You can use this button to calculate the customer's credit score.

 

  • Risk Class Determination:

Along with score calculation, the system will also determine the risk class based on the configuration set in "Create Risk Classes."

You can also manage various other parameters in Manage Credit Accounts App for your business partner from a credit management perspective, such as Credit Group, First Year of Customer Relationship, and more.

Note that I have only discussed the items we utilized from the perspective of our blog; there are many other aspects of master data relevant to credit management that are not covered here. This blog is intended for those who have a solid understanding of basic credit management.

 

Key Links:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/918bca53037f408f91a2295d04ac16bc/ba31db0b263a438c8640ec3731d0b640.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/918bca53037f408f91a2295d04ac16bc/6c529513913f427d8d73bd359cb74ca5.html

--------------------

Stay tuned for upcoming blogs on a variety of topics.

entry.title: Automatic Credit Limit Calculation in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
1. Credit Management

In SAP, credit management is a function within Financial Supply Chain Management (FSCM) that oversees and regulates customer credit limits to promote timely payments and minimize the risk of bad debt. Mainly these 3 scope items are responsible for Overall credit management function:

Basic Credit Management (BD6)

Advanced Credit Management (1QM)

Credit Agency Integration (1RY)

 

2. Automatic Credit Limit Calculation

Automatic Credit Limit Calculation is a feature of advanced credit management that streamlines the process of setting credit limits through automation. We will explore how the system is set up and operates to automatically determine credit limits.

Please note: This blog is intended for individuals who already have a fundamental understanding of basic credit management. Automatic Credit Limit Calculation is part of 1QM scope item.

 

Additionally, there is a separate blog for Automatic Credit Score Calculation available:

Automatic Credit Score Calculation in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

 

3. Scenario

We are going to calculate credit limit based on three condition such as

  • Last three months sales of the company code with the customer
  • Collateral
  • Risk Adjustment (Calculated Credit Limit adjustment based on Risk Class of the customer)

 

4. Related Configuration

Some configurations are managed through the configuration node (CBC or Manage Your Solution), while others are defined directly via various SAP Fiori Apps.

 

Process Step

App Name/ Config

Remarks

Credit Formula for Score and CL

Define Formulas [CBC]

Just the structure, values are filled with Fiori App

Rule for Scoring and Credit Limit, Rating procedure assignment

Create Rule for Scoring and Credit Limit Calculation [CBC]

 

Formula Parameters are created

Maintain Formula Parameters (App)

Formula Parameters are created and assigned to score formula group and limit formula

Formula is created

Manage Formula in Credit Management (App)

Formula is created (code is used previous one).
Simulation can be done

Valuation is assigned against the rules

Manage Credit Management Rules (app)

 

Credit Details are updated in Customer Master

Manage Credit Account

 

 

  • Define Formulas (CBC)

Here, we are only setting up the code and framework for the Credit Limit Formula. The logic will be incorporated later in the Manage Formula in Credit Management App. This same formula is assigned during the configuration process in the "Create Rule for Scoring and Credit Limit Calculation" section.

 

  • Create Rule for Scoring and Credit Limit Calculation (CBC)

Here, we create a rule which is used for credit score and Credit Limit calculation. The formula is assigned to a rule within both the Score folder and the Credit Limit folder. We will focus Credit Limit folder on this blog.

 

 Credit Limit Folder:

Here, we assign Segment and credit limit formula that we had created under ‘Define Formulas’

 Note: The Score Folder and Rating Procedure selection are primarily needed for credit score calculation. We will cover these in another blog titled Automatic Credit Score Calculation in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

 Note: This Credit Score Rule is assigned with Business Partner (Customer) in Manage Credit Account App. Please refrain from using the Maintain Business Partner App for credit management purposes. It is recommended to use the Manage Credit Account App instead. Using the Maintain Business Partner App may not yield the desired outcomes in some processes within Credit Management.

  

  • Manage Formula in Credit Management (App)

 

You can create Credit Limit Formula from Template or from scratch (create). We will create from scratch.

It is assigned to the formula you previously created in the configuration step "Define Formula."

Threshold and Rounding will be detailed in the sections below. Please pay close attention.

 

Credit Limit Formula Tab:

Change mode.

Multiple methods can be defined for calculating your credit limit formula. In our approach, we have considered the following factors:

The credit formula is divided into two sections: 1. Limit Demand and 2. Limit Adjustment.

 

Limit Demand:

We calculate the credit limit based on the total sales value from the last three months, plus the collateral value. For example, if your sales were Rs. 700 and collateral was valued at Rs. 300, then your credit limit would be calculated as Rs. 1000.

 

Limit Adjustment:

- If the Risk class is A (No Default Risk), the credit limit will be twice the Limit Demand (Rs. 1000 * 2 = Rs. 2000).

- If Risk Class is B (Low Default Risk), the credit limit will be 1.5 times the Limit Demand (Rs. 1000 * 1.5 = Rs. 1500).

- If Risk Class is D (High Default Risk), the credit limit will be 0.5 times the Limit Demand (Rs. 1000 * 0.5 = Rs. 500).

The credit score formula calculates the credit score, which automatically fetches the risk class based on the configuration (Create Risk Classes). This illustrates the integration between credit score calculation and credit limit adjustment, where the risk class plays a critical role in determining the adjusted credit limit.

 

Under Limit Demand: Operand 1 and Operand 2 are Formula Parameter and Result Parameter is a Text. The Result Parameter is a descriptive text you need to provide when defining it, and it can be anything that makes sense for the process. In our case, we have named it ‘Credit Limit Calculation’.

Under Limit Adjustment: Operand 1 is a Formula Parameter and Operand 2 is the Result Parameter from Limit Demand.

 

We have incorporated the following Formula Parameters in our Credit Limit Formula, which we will explore in detail in the subsequent step:

  1. ZSALE_H_3M (Sales from the Last 03 Months)
  2. COLLATERALS (Collaterals)
  3. RISK_ADJUSTMENT (Risk Adjustment)

Note: It is necessary to establish Formula Parameters prior to creating the Credit Limit Formula in the Manage Formula in Credit Management (App).

 

Credit Limit Simulation:

We can simulate the credit limit calculation for a specific business partner and segment to verify the functionality of our formula. You can expect the same results when performing calculations for the same customer in the Manage Credit Account App.

 

You can learn about Limit Adjustment, Rounding, and Threshold in the Manage Credit Management Rules Section.

 

  • Maintain Formula Parameters App

Numerous formula parameters are already available; ideally, you should use the standard ones, but it is also possible to create your own formula parameters.

 

Formula parameters can be categorized into two types:

  1. Formula Parameter for Score Calculation: Assigned to the Parameter Group for Score Formula (used in credit score formulas).
  2. Formula Parameter for Credit Limit Calculation: Assigned to the Parameter Group for Limit Formula (used in credit limit formulas).

 

In this blog, we will focus solely on the 'Parameter Category for Limit Formula'.

 

Let's explore the specifics of these three Formula Parameters

  1. ZSALE_H_3M (Last 03 Months Sales)
  2. COLLATERALS (Collaterals)
  3. RISK_ADJUSTMENT (Risk Adjustment)

If you create a custom Formula Parameter, it needs to be assigned to the appropriate folder. For example, we created a Formula Parameter called ZSALE_H_3M for credit limit calculation, which we then assigned to the Parameter Category for Limit Formula.

 

ZSALE_H_3M (Last 03 Months Sales)

 

COLLATERALS (Collaterals)

 

RISK_ADJUSTMENT (Risk Adjustment)

 

  • Manage Credit Management Rules

Here, valuation is mapped to specific rules.

We will explore the rules that are pertinent to the Credit Limit Formula:

  1. Formula: Credit Limit Rounding Rule
  2. Formula: Credit Limit Threshold
  3. Formula: Risk Adjustment

 

Formula: Credit Limit Rounding Rule

You can define it by Risk Class. In this instance, I have left the Risk Class field blank, meaning it applies to all Risk Classes in the system. With an amount of 100 and a rounding position of 2, along with a Rounding Rule of Up (Round Up), this configuration means if the system calculates a credit limit amount as Rs. 7056, it will round up to Rs. 7100.

 

Formula: Credit Limit Threshold

Continued screen shot

Here, we set the minimum and maximum values for credit limit calculations. If the minimum value is set at Rs. 6000, then the system will assign a credit limit of Rs. 6000, even if the calculated limit falls below Rs. 5999. Likewise, the system will not exceed the maximum value assigned here.

Note: You can establish multiple conditions and designate various lower and upper credit limit values based on factors such as Segment, Country, Risk Class, and Credit Group.

 

Formula: Risk Adjustment

Adjust the credit limit of a business partner depending on the risk class and credit segment.

Input a Risk Class to adjust the credit limits for. If you want the adjustment to apply to all credit segments, leave the Credit Segment field blank. The credit limit for the relevant business partners will be multiplied by the value entered in the Risk Adjustment field. Entering a factor of 1 in the Risk Adjustment field will leave the credit limit unchanged.

Entering a factor greater than 1 will increase the credit limit.

Entering a factor less than 1 will decrease the credit limit.

 

This is utilized in the 'Manage Formula in Credit Management App'. Please refer to that section for a detailed explanation.

 

 5. Master Data and Calculation Process

Master data such as:

  • Calculation Rule

Credit scores are computed at the business partner level, while credit limits are calculated at the segment level.

Note: The Calculation Rule (ZCRLIMIT) serves as the connection among all the configurations and settings implemented for calculating the credit limit.

 

  • Segment Tab (go to details): Credit Limit Calculation

Validity is derived from the configuration settings in Create Rule for Scoring and Credit Limit Calculation (CBC).

In the top right corner, you'll find a button marked in yellow "Calculate Credit Limit." This button appears in the segment section when in edit mode. Once you calculate the credit limit for the customer and segment combination, the remaining process will proceed as usual.

 

  • Collateral

Items like Collateral, Insurance, etc., can be maintained either at the Business Partner Level or the Segment Level, depending on the business scenario. It is feasible to maintain these values at both levels simultaneously.

Note that I have only discussed the items we utilized from the perspective of our blog; there are many other aspects of master data relevant to credit management that are not covered here. This blog is intended for those who have a solid understanding of basic credit management.Top of Form

 

Key Links:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/918bca53037f408f91a2295d04ac16bc/ba31db0b263a438c8640ec3731d0b640.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/918bca53037f408f91a2295d04ac16bc/8a35ffa389004b3a9f9b8b22ef81e3a1.html

 

----------------

Stay tuned for upcoming blogs on a variety of topics.

entry.title: Custom Fields (Characteristics) for Margin Analysis (Profitability Analysis) in S/4HANA Cloud Public
entry.content:
1. Basic Information about custom Characteristics (Custom Fields)
  • Key users can add custom fields to margin analysis by utilizing the "Accounting: Market Segment" business context.
  • You can add up to 120 custom fields using the "Accounting: Market Segment" business context.
  • With this context, you can include the following types of custom fields:
    • Code List (Recommended)
    •  Numerical Text
    • Text

 

  • Custom fields can be deleted even if postings have already been made using them.

 

  1. Custom Field (Characteristic) Creation

Custom Field App:

Clear Create (+)

Type option you have:

  • Code List (Recommended)
  • Numerical Text
  • Text

Click: Create and Edit

You need to activate the fields where they are required. Each section provides available options; identify your area of interest or need and activate the relevant fields accordingly.

We have Enabled below services under User Interfaces:

Cost Centers Actuals

Manage Journal Entries

Post General Journal Entries

Manage Recurring Journal Entries

Journal Entry Item and many other.

Save

and then Publish. It may take a while.

It got published.

 

  1. Inputting Values for Custom Fields

There are three following options to enter values for custom fields:

  • Substitution Rules

You can create substitution rules for custom fields through the "Accounting: Market Segment" business context, available in the Manage Substitution/Validation Rules app.

  • Manual Selection in Manual Entries

Field values for custom fields can be entered manually.

  • Substitution Using Business Add-In (BAdI)

The relevant enhancement option is the Business Add-In Market Segment Extension Fields Substitution (FINS_MARKET_SEGMENT_SUB), which allows you to determine extension characteristics using the market segment.

- Create a custom field through a pre-existing CDS view.

- Generate a custom field by creating a derivation rule through a custom business object.

- Develop a custom field based on another custom field that was previously derived.

(Please Consult with Technical Consultant)

Manage Substitution / Validation Rules – Journal Entry App

Create

 

Substitution Type: Substitute with Constant

Save

Then Activate.

 

  1. Transaction Posting with Manually Custom Fields Update

Create Outgoing Invoice (FI Customer Billing)

Region Field

Note: A functional consultant can manually derive a custom field (characteristic) or through substitution. However, if you wish to use BAdi, you will need to seek assistance from a technical consultant.

entry.title: How to restrict access to material types and material groups in SAP S4 HANA
entry.content:
Restricting access to material types and material groups in SAP S4 HANA 

In S4 HANA Procurement, material types and material groups are restricted using authorization objects M_MATE_MAR (Material Master: Material Types) and M_MATE_WGR (Material Master: Material Groups). Both these objects have a common field value called BEGRU (Authorization group).

Material types and material groups cannot be directly maintained in BEGRU. First, use the Tcode SE54 to create authorization groups. The authorization groups must then be mapped to material types and groups using the T-codes OMS2 and OMSF. Then these authorization groups should be maintained in a role.

Note: Material types with no authorization group will skip the M_MATE_MAR authority check. material groups with no authorization group will skip M_MATE_WGR. Hence, authorization groups should be maintained against all the material types (allowed and restricted) and material groups (allowed and restricted) to make the access restrictions work.

 

Authorization object

Description

Field1

Description

Field2

Description

M_MATE_MAR

(Material Master: Material Types)

Actvt

Activity

BEGRU

Authorization group

M_MATE_WGR

(Material Master: Material Groups)

Actvt

Activity

BEGRU

Authorization group

Let us look at an example of restricting users' access to specific material types and groups while using the T-codes MM01, MM02, and MM03.

Material types allowed for users – Goods. All the other material types other than Goods should be restricted for users.

Material groups allowed for users - Finance Services. All the other material groups other than Finance Services should be restricted for users.

Two sets of authorization groups should be created in SE54 for the case described above.

Z001 for allowed material types.

Z002 for restricted material types.

Z003 for allowed material groups.

Z004 for restricted material groups.

Steps:

  • Create authorization groups for material types and material groups using the Tcode SE54.

  • Map authorization groups with the material types using the Tcode OMS2 (maintain the authorization group Z001 against the allowed material types (Goods) and maintain the authorization group Z002 against all the restricted material types.)

  • Map authorization groups with the material groups using the T-code OMSF (maintain the authorization group Z003 against all the allowed material groups (Finance Services) and maintain the authorization group Z004 against all the restricted material groups.)

  • Maintain the authorization groups in the authorization objects (M_MATE_MAR and M_MATE_WGR) in PFCG.

entry.title: SAP Activate and Scaled Agile Framework Playbook is publicly available
entry.content:
The October 2024 release of the SAP Activate Roadmap Viewer, supporting the  SAP Activate Methodology for RISE with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition journey, introduces the SAP Activate and Scaled Agile Framework Playbook as an accelerator in the Prepare phase.

This playbook serves as a practical resource for teams embarking on S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition implementations in organizations utilizing the Scaled Agile Framework (SAFe) to enhance their agile deployment practices.

Below are additional references to assist organizations in aligning both methodologies effectively :

  • SAP Activate and Scaled Agile Framework Playbook
  • Innovate Faster: The Power Duo of SAP Activate and SAFe
  • Working with SAFe Epics in the SAP Activate Discover phase
  • Managing SAP Activate Prepare and Explore phases with SAFe
  • SAP Activate Realize and Deploy phase activities in SAFe

entry.title: Breathing New Life into SAP Brownfield+: 5 Challenges and 5 Steps with BTP, UX, and Innovation Trife
entry.content:
Background

Brownfield projects+, while offering a tempting shortcut to expansion, come with their own set of hurdles. Despite the acknowledged limitations of brownfield+ upgrades compared to greenfield projects, many customers are drawn to this approach due to the significant risks and costs associated with greenfield implementations.

The Challenge and The Step

1. Integrated Legacy Systems: The Weight of the Past

Outdated integrated systems is a common obstacle in brownfield projects. Integrating new systems with legacy infrastructure can lead to compatibility issues, data silos, and security vulnerabilities and may also need clients to rewire the integrations to the new system.

Consolidation of Integrations: . We should begin by ranking each integration based on its business criticality and the potential positive business impact of modernization. We still need to rewire all the old integrations to the new SAP Brownfield + systems and test them to ensure that data is flowing through correctly and processes are working as expected. This may be right time for us to assess whether rewiring or upgrading middle-ware or redesigning interfaces using new BTP technologies is the right thing to do based on risk vs reward vs cost.

 

Conquer Integration Chaos

1. Minimize Integration Debt: Identify and eliminate unnecessary integrations, focusing on those that deliver clear business value.

2. Prioritize Integration Journeys: Define and prioritize key integration journeys that directly impact business efficiencies and outcomes.

3. Establish Integration Standards:Implement clear standards and best practices for future integrations to ensure consistency, maintainability, and scalability.

2. Data Inconsistencies: Unearthing Hidden Treasures

Brownfield+ projects often inherit messy data landscapes. Inconsistent formats, duplicate entries, and poor data quality hinder decision-making and operational efficiency.

Unearthing Hidden Treasures : Now is the ideal time to uncover valuable data assets and establish robust data governance. We should identify business processes where analytic insights and improving poor data quality can yield significant business benefits. Then, we can define and implement appropriate data policies and governance mechanisms to ensure data accuracy, consistency, and reliability in these areas.

 

3 data gold mine tips, link process and data and analytics KPI's together !
  1. Fill Data Holes : Leverage process mining tools to identify data holes that are causing process inefficiencies
  2. Magnify : Assess and rank both business processes and data objects based on their potential business value and impact on desired outcomes.
  3. Build Process and Data Telescope : Prioritize process analytic insights and attributes that helps to see your business and processes in different dimensions and re-think analytic journey and get data quality right.

3. Spice up the Brownfield+ User Adoption: Use the UX as a cornerstone

Don't let UX become an afterthought in brownfield+ projects, this can be crucial factor to sell your S4 HANA brownfield + business case to business! Prioritize customer and business user experience by identifying key customer and business persona journeys that would benefit from a refresh. Leverage the power of generative AI, Web4, and 5G technologies to seamlessly embed modern and engaging UX elements into these end to end journeys.

 

Don't think SAP, think journeys end to end to identify areas of highest business impact!
  1. Engage UX and Business Experts : Conduct a poll to identify customer and business journeys that can be improved
  2. Heart the high impact UX journeys : Map user journeys to business KPI's and get businesses to heart/like the UX journeys that will be be very useful to business
  3. Magic Business UX Value Formulae : Use Gen AI to map UX journeys to value case and develop UX Journeys cost vs value case

4. Grease the Wheels and Prune the Code

While achieving a pristine core codebase might seem like a distant dream in brownfield+ projects with extensive legacy code, remember that even seemingly insurmountable challenges can be overcome with bold vision and determined action. If Elon Musk can revolutionize the automotive and aerospace industries, surely we can find innovative ways to streamline SAP codebase. Let's not be daunted by the scale of the task, but instead, approach it with the same spirit of innovation and ambition that drives groundbreaking achievements.

 

May not be fully clean but easier to scale in future
  1. Trimming the Fat : Time for some code spring cleaning! Let's hunt down those unused custom objects and code, then hit delete and free up some space in our system
  2. Polish Your Custom Crown Jewels : Let's sharpen our competitive edge! We'll leverage cutting-edge BTP,AI and cloud technologies to revamp and supercharge the custom objects that set us apart in the market.
  3. No More Code Clutter: Time for a Fresh Future: Let's create a sunset plan for currently, moderately used, outdated code. We'll map out how to redesign or retire this existing code, set clear expiration dates, and establish guidelines to ensure all new custom code is future-proof and aligned with our long-term goals.

5. Create a Landscape That Bends, Not Breaks

ERP and legacy modernization projects often become overly complex and costly due to a perfect storm of challenges: inadequate documentation, lack of automated testing for continuous improvement, a poor understanding of existing data and processes, and insufficient availability of crucial business resources. Brownfield+ projects offer a prime opportunity to **bleep** these recurring project nightmares in the bud.

 

DevOps: The Conductor of Operational Symphony
  1. Instant Process Mapping where Gen AI Meets Signavio : Leverage new Gen AI and Signavio tools to augment your process flows and generate documentations for critical end to end process scenarios.
  2. Shift Gears for Continuous Automated Testing : Don't let those end-to-end brownfield test scripts gather dust! Automate them, document them, and turn them into a valuable asset for future testing and maintenance of your brownfield project.
  3. The Change Express for delivering value non-stop : Reuse change management training and enable continuous release mechanisms where possible to deploy applications quicker where possible using new GIT frameworks. Let's inject some fun into change management! Imagine a Gen AI bot as your guide, helping you create engaging podcasts, interactive diagrams, and other creative content to communicate process changes in a fun and memorable way.

By embracing a strategic blend of BTP, UX design, and a forward-thinking mindset, we can transform brownfield projects into catalysts for innovation and growth.

Now go forth and conquer those brownfield challenges! We have the power to transform brownfield limitations into strategic advantages.

Don't shy away from bold goals. Even seemingly daunting legacy systems can be modernized and optimized for a brighter future.
Prioritize user experience. A seamless and intuitive UX can make all the difference in driving user adoption and maximizing the value of your brownfield investment.
Embrace automation and continuous improvement. From code optimization to testing and deployment, automation is key to unlocking efficiency and agility.
Make it fun! Change management doesn't have to be dry and tedious. Inject creativity and engagement into the process to inspire your team and stakeholders.

entry.title: The RFP Revolution: From Box-Ticking to Perfect-Fit SAP Partnerships
entry.content:
This year, I've witnessed a fascinating contrast in the world of SAP RFPs. I've had the opportunity to be involved in both ends of the spectrum: from exciting, purpose-driven proposals that prioritized value and innovation to more traditional, checklist-based approaches.

It's been inspiring to see clients championing this shift towards a more collaborative and value-focused selection process for their SAP implementation partners. I'm eager to share my observations and insights on how this transformation is unfolding and what it means for the future of successful SAP projects. I'm also keen to hear about your own experiences and perspectives on this evolving landscape.

1. From Requirements List to Interactive Blueprint:

Traditional: A lengthy document outlining every technical specification, often stifling creativity and limiting the exploration of innovative solutions.

Modern: Host a collaborative workshop where client and potential partners jointly develop a visual blueprint of the desired future state. This interactive approach encourages open dialogue, challenges assumptions, and fosters a shared understanding of the vision.

2. From Price Comparisons to Value-Based Assessments:

Traditional: A focus on the lowest bid, often leading to compromises on quality, experience, and long-term value.

Modern: Request a "Value Proposition Canvas" from each potential partner. This canvas outlines the partner's understanding of your key business pains, their proposed solutions, and the quantifiable value they aim to deliver. This shifts the focus from cost to return on investment.

3. From One-Size-Fits-All to Tailored Proof of Concepts:

Traditional: Generic presentations and case studies that may not resonate with your specific challenges.

Modern: Challenge potential partners to develop a tailored Proof of Concept (POC) addressing a critical business problem you face. This provides tangible evidence of their expertise, problem-solving approach, and ability to deliver tangible results.

4. From Formal Interviews to "Day in the Life" Simulations:

Traditional: Structured interviews that may not reveal true team dynamics and cultural fit.

Modern: Conduct a "Day in the Life" workshop where your team and the potential partner collaborate on a simulated project scenario. This provides valuable insights into communication styles, problem-solving approaches, and overall team synergy.

5. From Static Documents to Dynamic Collaboration Platforms:

Traditional: Paper-based or static digital RFPs that limit interaction and feedback.

Revolutionized: Utilize collaborative platforms that allow for real-time communication by asking intelligent questions, document sharing, and feedback loops throughout the RFP process. This fosters transparency, encourages engagement, and ensures everyone is aligned.

The RFP Revolution: A Call to Action

By embracing these concrete examples and adopting a more collaborative, value-driven, and holistic approach, we can transform the RFP process from boring check list document into a catalyst for forging truly trans-formative SAP partnerships. Let's modernize the procurement landscape together!

Here's how we can reshape the traditional RFP's commercial strategy, shifting from a cost-centric approach to one that fuels innovation:

Traditional RFP (Cost Focus) ➡️ Revolutionized RFP (Innovation Focus)

Price-Driven Selection ➡️ Value-Based Assessment:

Old: Lowest bidder often wins, potentially sacrificing quality and long-term value.

New: Evaluate proposals on Total Cost of Ownership (TCO), ROI projections, and the partner's commitment to continuous improvement and value delivery.

Fixed Scope & Requirements ➡️ Agile & Outcome-Oriented:

Old: Rigidly defined scope limits flexibility for innovative solutions to emerge during the project.

New: Define desired business outcomes and allow for iterative development, incorporating new technologies or approaches as needed.

Payment Tied to Deliverables ➡️Shared Risk & Reward Models:

Old: Vendor gets paid for completing tasks, even if the overall solution doesn't meet expectations.

New: Explore gain-sharing agreements, outcome-based pricing, or joint innovation funds to incentivize partners to deliver exceptional results.

Key Questions to Ask Potential Partners (Innovation Focus):

  1. How will you leverage emerging technologies (e.g., AI, automation) to drive innovation and efficiency in our SAP implementation? Give an example of your business problem to solve!

  2. Can you provide examples of how you've helped other clients in our industry achieve breakthrough results through innovative SAP solutions?

  3. How will you ensure that our SAP implementation remains flexible and adaptable to future business changes and technological advancements?Give an example of your business problem to solve!

  4. What is your approach to knowledge transfer and co-innovation, ensuring that our team is empowered to drive ongoing innovation with SAP? Give an example of your business problem to solve!

entry.title: SAP BTP BRH (Batch Release Hub for Life Sciences) Application Extension
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Batch Release Hub for Life Sciences is your central point of access to the information necessary for

making fast and accurate release decisions in the pharmaceutical industry.

As a person involved in the release decision process, SAP Batch Release Hub for Life Sciences provides you with the information you need to prepare, review, and make compliant release decisions. By centralizing the relevant data from diverse source systems in one place, the solution helps you manage the complexity of the release decision process and detect any deviations early in the process.

 

Integration Options

Depending on business needs, SAP Batch Release Hub for Life Sciences can be integrated with a variety

of source systems such as follows:

  • SAP S/4HANA
  • SAP Advanced Track and Trace for Pharmaceuticals
  • Laboratory information management system (LIMS)
  • Regulatory information management system (RIMS)
  • Quality management system (QMS)
  • Manufacturing execution system (MES)
  • SAP Global Batch Traceability (SAP GBT)
  • SAP Intelligent Clinical Supply Management

 

In our case we are integrating SAP BRH with S/4HANA.

 

Architecture

  

Requirement.

SAP BRH APPLICATION UI EXTENSTION.

 

  1. Introduce a few new fields with possible values Stop Shipment, SUQ, Obsolete which is mapped from the S4 app.

 

Field ID

Field Description

Type

Length

ZZ_Reason_Rest

Reason for Restriction

String

200

ZZ_Batch_Status

Batch status

String

1

 

  1. Below are the CDS data models need to extend to achieve the same
  • BatchesCore
  • BatchesService
  1. Below are the fields need to be added while extending entity for BatchesCore and BatchesService
  • ZZ_Reason_Rest - Reason for Restriction
  • ZZ_Batch_Status - Batch status
  1. Extend the BatchesStage and BatchesActive UI to for extended fields.

To achieve the above requirement we are going to extend UI and DB table SAP BTP.

  • Frontend extension (UI) – to extend the view
  • Extending Native SAP S/4 HANA Integration

 

Development

Frontend Development on BTP.

 

  1. To Extend the field we should have BAS (Business Application Studio) service activated BTP Sub Account.
  2. Once we have service activated, we should login into the cloud foundry and start the development.

              

 

 

  1. Open The Terminal and install the appropriate version of @Priya0/cds-dk as follows

Version of SAP Batch Release Hub for Life Sciences

SDK Version

Command

2406

7.7.2

npm install -g @Priya0/cds-dk@7.7.2

 

 

 

  1. Create a new Directory / Project into the BAS through UI / below command also  can be used to create directory.

Command to create Directory - mkdir brh_ext_company_short_name_01

Go inside the rectory and execute command - cd brh_ext_company_short_name_01

 

  1. After creating Directory please create a file ( package.Json)  and mention the project which you want to extend.

Below is the command to achieve the same.

touch package.json and after that put below JSON into the file.

{ "name": "brh-ext-1",

  "extends": "_base" }

 

Note – Above Step is very important step to pull the project otherwise it will give error.

  1. To extend any project we should have Extension.cds file inside the app folder. Lets create that too with the command, you can do it through the UI also.

“Mkdir app” and once folder created go inside the folder and execute “touch Extension.cds” command.

 

  1. Similarly create a i18n folder and under this create file called i18n.properties

Now the important step is to pull the project which you want to extend. Use the below command for the same.
Syntax - cds pull -s <subdomain> --from <brh-mtx-url>

 

 

Command - cds pull -s ***-mt-dev-eu --from https://iron-preprod-preprod-iron-     mtx.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com

Password -  when will you start pulling the project it will ask for the password.

You can get a valid passcode at:

Syntax - https://<subdomain>.authentication.<landscape>.hana.ondemand.com/passcode

Command - https://***-mt-dev-eu.authentication.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/passcode

  1. Once you are done with extension in Extension.CDS file and i18n file lets buid the project and push it to repository / server. With the following command.

Command – CDS Build

 

Once your build is finished you will get the following message like build completed in 2369 ms

at the end.

   

 

 

  1. After Build lets push the project to the Cloud / Server.

Syntax - cds push -s <subdomain> --to <brh-mtx-url>

Command - cds push -s ***-mt-dev-eu --to https://iron-preprod-preprod-iron-mtx.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com

Password -  will generate the password in same manner as pulling the file / project.

Syntax - https://<subdomain>.authentication.<landscape>.hana.ondemand.com/passcode

Command - https://***-mt-dev-eu.authentication.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/passcode

 

 You will get Activation succeeded message in couple of second after entering the command. Now your changes are live please check in to the application.

Integration (Extending Native SAP S/4HANA Integration) Development

Extensibility provides customers with the flexibility to adapt the SAP Life Sciences defined model to

accommodate custom attributes that are specific to the business on master and transaction data objects.

The goal of extensibility is to enable customers to extend APIs with custom data. A simple case would be adding single fields, a more complex case would be to add array fields or add child entities.

For the extensions to work seamlessly, customers should make the changes in the Integration Hub, SAP S/4HANA, and Batch Release Hub tenant keeping the field names the same across all the applications.

 

Extensions for SAP BTP

This section contains information about creating customer extensions for Integration Hub for Life Sciences in SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP).

Customers can access all base entity models in the application and can add non-key and non-mandatory fields to the entity by extending the model. These additions should be on the root level of the entity. The field names are case-sensitive. The following default prefixes are allowed for custom attributes:

  • Z_
  • ZZ_
  • Y_
  • YY_

Note - Any other prefix will result in an activation error.

 

Prerequisites

  • You have read the Cloud Application Programming Model documentation (Extending SaaS Applications ).
  • You have been assigned the required role. You must be assigned with the CDS Extension Development access role collection for Integration Hub for Life Sciences, because it contains the cds.ExtensionDeveloper scope, which is required by the cds.xt.Extensibility service. Otherwise, you will get a "403 forbidden" error.
  • You have set up your development environment as follows:
  • We recommend using Nodejs 18 or higher.
  • You must use @Priya0/cds-dk version 7.0.0 or higher.
  • Install and update @Priya0/cds-dk globally by running npm i -g @Priya0/cds-dk@^7.

 

Development

  1. Log on to the BAP BTP BAS (Business Application Studio) and in Cloud foundry.
  2. Create another project in same way we did for frontend model extension:

               Project Name (Folder)

                             DB(Folder)

                             Node_modules(Folder)

                             Package.json(File)

          

 

                  

  1. Once structure is ready. Let’s add the code below to the package.json file. And add extension.cds file in DB folder.

{

    "name": "ihls-extension-project",

    "version": "1.0.0",

    "description": "IHLS extension project",

    "cds": {

        "extends": "_base"

    },

    "dependencies": {

        "@sap/cds-dk": "^7.7.2"

    }

}

 

 

  1. Once your structure is ready let’s pull the project in the same manner we did above. Run the below command line.

Syntax - npx cds pull -s <tenant-subdomain> --from <ihlssubscribed-core-app-url>

Command - npx cds pull -s ***-mt-dev-eu --to https://***-mt-dev-eu-validation-lsifs -core.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com

 

  1. After pulling project lets start development

Since we are extending Batch entity lets find entity in S4 side , for this go to the index.csn file in node_modules folder and search for the Batch, and copy the sap.ihls.batch.Batch.

Please see the screenshot below for the same.

 

 

  1. Now lets modify the extension.cds file in DB folder, and the entity and fields like below.

using {

    sap.ihls.batch.Batch,

} from '_base';

extend entity Batch with {

 

    ZZ_ReasonRest  : String;

    ZZ_BatchStatus : String;

}

 

Once this development is done, lets push the code with below command.

 

Syntax - npx cds push -s <tenant-subdomain> --from <ihlssubscribed-core-app-url>

Command - npx cds push -s ***-mt-dev-eu --to https://***-mt-dev-eu-validation-lsifs -core.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com

 

 

 

 

 

After pushing the code to the server now you should see S4 data in the added field.

 

Note – Don’t forget to enhance BADI in the backend(S4) side for added fields. 😊

entry.title: CDS Abstract Entity and ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model: Input parameter modelling.
entry.content:
1. Using Abstract Entities for Non-Standard RAP BO Operations.

This short overview of abstract entities concept in the context of non-standard RAP business object operations. It outlines their purpose, advantages, and implementation strategies, emphasizing their role in enhancing modularity and flexibility in data modeling.

Purpose.

Abstract entities are Core Data Services (CDS) constructs specifically designed to model complex input parameters for non-standard RAP BO operations(actions and functions).

Database Independence

One of the key features of abstract entities is their independence from database persistence. They are particularly suited for parameter modeling and give possibility to redefine parameters on next modelling level.

Reusability.

Abstract entities promote reusability across multiple operations. This characteristic enables developers to adopt a more modular approach, allowing the same abstract entity to be utilized in different contexts without the need for redundant definitions.

Parameter Flexibility.

These entities support complex structures, including multi-level nested components. This flexibility allows for more sophisticated data representations and enhances the capability to handle intricate business logic.

Binding.

Unlike traditional entities, abstract entities are not bound to specific BO nodes. They provides greater adaptability in how they are integrated into various operations.

Improved Separation of Concerns.

By decoupling input parameter modeling from the actual business logic, abstract entities facilitate a clearer separation of concerns. This simplification in design leads to more maintainable and understandable code, as the focus can be placed on each aspect of the application independently.

In conclusion, abstract entities serve as a powerful tool for modeling complex input parameters in non-standard RAP BO operations.

2. Implementation details.

I want to highlight how to effectively use abstract entities in ABAP development. One of their key applications is for typing, particularly for action parameters in RAP actions. Let’s begin with a straightforward example.

We make a simple abstract entity with four fields.

 

@EndUserText.label: 'ABSTRACT ENTITY'
define root abstract entity ZPRU_ABS_ENTITY
{
    ABSTRACTENTITYNAME : char40;
    SURNAME : char40;
    AGE : int4;
    EMAIL : char40;
    
    CHILD : composition [ * ] of ZPRU_ABS_CHILD;
    CHILD_2: composition [ * ] of ZPRU_ABS_CHILD_2;
}

 

Next, I created a RAP business object with a root entity view (the specifics of which aren’t important for this example) and defined the 'sendEntity' action with an input parameter of type ZPRU_ABS_ENTITY.

Let’s have a look at action definition:

 

managed implementation in class zbp_pru_root_entity unique;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for ZPRU_ROOT_ENTITY alias ROOT
persistent table zpru_dn
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
{
  create;
  update;
  delete;
  field ( readonly ) dn_no, freq, prod;

  //Flat
  action sendEntity parameter ZPRU_ABS_ENTITY;
  // Deep
  action sendEntity2 deep parameter ZPRU_ABS_ENTITY;
  // Deep Table
  action sendEntity3 deep table parameter ZPRU_ABS_ENTITY;

}

 

Right now, let’s check RAP business object implementation class.

 

CLASS lhc_root DEFINITION INHERITING FROM cl_abap_behavior_handler.
  PRIVATE SECTION.

    METHODS get_instance_authorizations FOR INSTANCE AUTHORIZATION
      IMPORTING keys REQUEST requested_authorizations FOR root RESULT result.

    METHODS sendentity2 FOR MODIFY
      IMPORTING keys FOR ACTION root~sendentity2.

    METHODS sendentity FOR MODIFY
      IMPORTING keys FOR ACTION root~sendentity.

    METHODS sendentity3 FOR MODIFY
      IMPORTING keys FOR ACTION root~sendentity3.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS lhc_root IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD get_instance_authorizations.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD sendentity2.
    DATA(lv_deep_field_from_abs_entity) = keys[ 1 ]-%param-child[ 1 ]-abstractchildname.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD sendentity.
    DATA(lv_field_from_abs_entity) = keys[ 1 ]-%param-abstractentityname.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD sendentity3.
    DATA(lv_deep_table_field) = keys[ 1 ]-%param[ 1 ]-child[ 1 ]-abstractchildname.
  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

 

Derived type:

As a result, you'll see the KEYS table, where each row contains a %PARAM component. This component is typed as the structure ZPRU_ABS_ENTITY.

The next step is to demonstrate the use of the 'deep parameter AbstractBDEF' and the 'deep table parameter AbstractBDEF' in defining a BDEF action parameter.

To do this, we need to extend the abstract entity by adding a BDEF of type Abstract with a hierarchy.

First, I added the 'root' keyword to the abstract entity:

One important note: when adding a BDEF to an abstract entity, we initiate the creation of an abstract business object. As a result, we need to construct this business object in a way that's quite similar to how we build standard RAP business objects. This is why we use keywords like 'root', 'composition', and 'association to parent.'

I also created a new abstract entity, ZPRU_ABS_CHILD. Then, I added mutual associations between ZPRU_ABS_ENTITY as the root and ZPRU_ABS_CHILD as the child.

 

Then, I’ve created BDEF with ZPRU_ABS_ENITY as root entity and Abstract implementation type:

 Let’s overview new abstract BDEF:

 

abstract;
strict ( 2 );
with hierarchy;

define behavior for ZPRU_ABS_ENTITY alias ABS
{
  association CHILD;
  association CHILD_2;
}

define behavior for ZPRU_ABS_CHILD alias CHILD
{

  association ROOT;

}

define behavior for zpru_abs_child_2 {

association third_level;

}

 

There are 3 main points:

  1.  add keyword ‘with hierarchy’ to make BDEF opt to deep expanding.
  2. recreate RAP BO composition tree, add root entity and child entity.
  3. explicitly mark association to ZPRU_ABS_CHILD.

Finally, I’ve added addition keyword ‘deep’ to action definition to expand action parameter type.

Let’s have a look into typing:

%PARAM typing:

You can notice that to component %PARAM a new nested table with the name CHILD has been added. It’s an effect of keyword ‘deep’ in action parameter definition. Component CHILD has type of table due to cardinality [ * ] in definition of composition in abstract root entity ZPRU_ABS_ENTITY.

Last topic is about addition ‘deep table’ to action parameter definition.

Let’s add it:

Hence, let’s check what has been changed in typing:

As you can see component %PARAM became table, before it was a structure. This is the effect of keyword ‘table’ in action parameter definition.

Lastly, the same principles apply to typing action output parameters. However, one key difference is that we can't use the 'deep' addition when defining output parameters. As a result, the %PARAM component will be incorporated into the output's derived type as a structure.

A table with summarizing:

entry.title: SAP Community Question: In your opinion, what's the biggest use-case for Blockchain at SAP Customers
entry.content:
Good Morning SAP Community,

in your opinion what is _the_ biggest use case for Enterprise Blockchain / Distributed Ledger Technology at SAP Customers ?

Anybody following my blogs will know I like Enterprise Blockchain, and am interested in positioning Enterprise Blockchain as a Technology Standard for use-cases and business demands at SAP Customers enabling them to run Enterprise Blockchain.

I talk to a lot of people about this and regularly get asked the same question, what is _the_ BIG use case for Blockchain in the Enterprise and at SAP Customers ?

So, the floor is open, the comments are open, there is no wrong answer, and everybody is invited to give their opinion on,

for SAP Customers, what is the biggest use case for Blockchain ?

Over to you, feel welcome to put your thoughts in the comments and let's see what we discover, and, there is no wrong answer 🙂

Andy Silvey.

entry.title: 🧰👷‍♂️ The SAP S/4HANA RISE & SAP BTP - Toolbox 👷‍♂️🧰
entry.content:
The SAP S/4HANA PCE Private Cloud Edition on RISE & SAP BTP

    🧰👷‍Toolbox for SAP Technology Architects & SAP Basis Administrators 👷‍🧰

[This blog is updated daily - and please note, this blog is not about the pros and cons, this blog is to help me and anybody else who is anywhere on the journey]

Having found this "RISE & BTP 1 Pager for Technical Architects & SAP Basis Administrators", if you're interested in this subject, then subscribe to the SAP Innovation and Transformation newsletter, here's the link:  Innovation & Transformation Newsletter SAP Services and Support and to the weekly SAP News Center Newsletter: SAP News Center Newsletter the technology is evolving so fast it is more important than ever to stay up to date, and subscribe to the SAP Enterprise Support Academy newsletter.

RISE with SAP , S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition, (btw - if you don't have time to read this then just click that link and read all the links in there) is re-writing the book on how companies "do" SAP, and in fact, everybody on that journey or planning for or preparing for that journey is re-writing the book.

The blog, the toolbox covers pretty much _all_ aspects of the SAP Private Cloud Edition (s) journey, all Phases, and across all technologies and everything that will be touched and goes deep in to the SAP Basis Administration tasks for setting up and establishing and operational readiness of SAP Private Cloud systems and the BTP and everything around it. The blog is updated on a daily basis, I use it as my own Toolbox and if it helps others then that's great. The subject is so big that it spilled over in to the comments. The goal is one page so that it can be searched with CTRL-F. If you need something and cannot find it, then write in the comments what you are looking for or send me a DM and I will show you where it is and if I don't know somebody else will.

The interesting thing is, as we move towards 2026, the move to S/4HANA is no longer only about S/4HANA Private (or Public) Cloud Edition or S/4HANA Cloud Private or RISE or whatever you call it, the move to S/4 has turned into a modernisation of the whole IT Platform.

Look at this presentation of "Transition to S/4HANA" from 2017.....

The Path to S/4HANA: Transition Scenarios and Best Practices

Back then, we were only thinking about the "upgrade to S/4HANA", back then in 2017 the SAP Cloud Platform, now the SAP BTP Business Technology Platform was in its infancy and basically only SAP Cloud Platform Integration and Mobile Services.

Now, let's say 9 years later, coming in to 2026, the move to S/4 is triggering a modernisation (or transformation) of the whole IT Stack/.Tool Set, the S/4 as the Core and everything around it from Data (Master Data), Integration (APIs/Events), Security (System/BTP Hardening, E2E Integration, Users RnA, Provisioning), Extension/Custom Development (Clean Core), Monitoring, User Experience,  Reporting & Analytics, Operations, Organisation,  and of course Innovation, where innovation is lead by AI in all of its forms.

And it's not only the S/4HANA on RISE anymore, it's all of the OnPremise Editions moving to RISE Private Cloud Editions, not many years ago we were unsure of the future of products like SAP GRC AC and now we can see that SAP GRC2026 is coming and that will have the same end of life as the S/4HANA, currently 2040, and where will we be running that, as a Private Cloud Edition on RISE ECS. And it's the same for the rest of the products like GTS, ATTP etc, if their end of life is 2040 then they will be moving to PCE RISE ECS.

And what about the BW's ?  Our legacy BW's BW on HANA, BW/4HANA are going to move to the BDC Business Data Cloud as PCE Private Cloud Editions on BDC. And so, this subject is evolving before our eyes. This is interesting, BW's are not going to RISE ECS Private Cloud, they are going to BDC Private Cloud.

What we are part of is, in my opinion, is a once in a generation, once in a lifetime technology change and learning opportunity.

And so this blog, is here to help me, and others, across the holistic subject of SAP modernisation. There is so much to learn, so many new things, and the majority of it is on this page. The page is updated on a daily basis with everything new that I touch are learn.

So let's get in to it...

There are so many myths and misunderstandings about RISE, hopefully this work will shine more light on the subject.

The goal of this work is to provide a SAP S/4 RISE & BTP "1 Pager" for all of us Customer/System Integrator side folks who are on this journey. 

This is where you are coming from and going to as a SAP Customer and as an Individual...

The SAP Business Suite Advantage https://dam.sap.com/mac/app/p/pdf/asset/preview/mEz8n1W?h=&ltr=a

For me, there are at least five high level dimensions to this S/4 RISE BTP journey:

SAP Next Generation ERP - Getting to S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition

SAP Managed Cloud Infrastructure -  Getting running on SAP RISE

SAP Cloud Enterprise Applications - Getting the BTP 

SAP Customer Organisational Change - SAP North Star Architecture

SAP AI & Intelligent Technologies & Automation & New Innovations & RoadMap Opportunities - get them as soon as possible across all dimensions - functions - units  - domains - processes

All five of the dimensions, and more, are covered in this 1 pager.

Moving quickly from those five high level dimensions and down in to the lower level engine room impact of the S/4HANA RISE BTP journey,  it must be clearly understood,  that, an S/4HANA RISE Program is actually all of this and more....

a Project Management / Program Management Transformation  - the program is huge and has a specific proven approach, Activate, which people need to learn

a Data Transformation - the Data is changing, and the structures

a Process Transformation - processes are changing

a Technical Basis Transformation - Basis technologies are changing and how you do Basis

an Integration Transformation - integrations (API Events) and the tools (Broker) are changing

a Hosting Transformation - hosting is changing

a User Experience Transformation - User Experience and User Interfacee is changing

an Operations Transformation - how you do Operations is changing

a Security Transformation - Security is changing, eg how to secure end to end API integrations across Authentication and Authorisation at all layers 

a Monitoring Transformation - monitoring is changing

a Tools Transformation - the tools you use are changing

a Custom Development (Extensions) Transformation - how you do extensions and where is changing

an Organisational Transformation (whether you like it or not) - your organisation will have to change, the old set up will be inefficient

a Roles & Responsibilities Transformation - roles will change

a People Transformation - people will need new skills

a Testing Transformation - there will be so much testing required - end to end

a New Technology Transformation - there will be so much new tech starting with Joule....

a to-be-architecture Legacy System transformation - as in legacy which remains as transition or part of the to-be will need to adapt

How to solve that ?

The very first thing to do is read and digest SAP's 10 Underlying Quality Principles.

Implementing and Migrating to and Running S/4 PCE on RISE for the last three years, there is so much to learn and the SAP technology is changing faster these days than I have seen in my whole career, there is so much to keep up with, and similarly for the BTP, having been doing BTP (or as it was the SAP Cloud Platform) for 7 years, the BTP is moving very fast, new Services, existing Services evolving.

The two subjects are combined, SAP S/4HANA PCE on RISE with BTP, because in my eyes the two go hand in hand, S/4HANA PCE on RISE is the next generation of the previous On-Premise ERP offerings from SAP, and the BTP contains the next generation of Applications which we will all use with the S/4HANA PCE on RISE.

And then, since we are on this RISE journey, we are going to need to change our SAP CoE organisation, the existing SAP CoE setup will not be optimal for working with RISE/ECS, and so there's a section on SAP Organisational Change Management, SAP Center of Excellence, and SAP North Star Architecture. 

The SAP North Star Architecture Service will safe guard the whole journey, from evaluation to run and everything in between, if you have the money, it's a must have, on the other hand, can you afford to go on the S/4 RISE BTP journey and not invest in safe guarding with the SAP North Star Architecture Service ?

And then, the final section is lessons learned :-), what can we learn from previous implementations and bring to the next implementation.

In my whole career I have never seen the pace of new SAP Technology move so fast and so wide. One of the phenomena which never ceases to amaze me these days is as the front end and user experience becomes easier, the back complexity goes up exponentially, as we make the front end more simple we make the backend more complex.

Please expect to find changes and new information here, because it will be a live work in progress.

Hopefully this toolbox will accelerate you as much as it will accelerate me.

This is the journey you are going on...

How do you do RISE ?

Regardless of what anybody thinks about all of the different methodologies, every SAP Customer who is contemplating the move to S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition on RISE must begin by reading about the "RISE with SAP Methodology".

This is basically a guided procedure including supporting documentation to help SAP Customers get to S/4HANA in the smoothest and straightest line possible.

SAP Quality Awards for Customer Success | SAP Quality

Anchor Business Value Firmly in your Project and Start Scoping Early

Section 1.01] The SAP & Customer Shared Responsibilities on RISE

The goal of this section is to help the SAP Customer who is thinking about RISE to build a clear picture and understanding of what the responsibilities are and what the segregation of duties are.

A lot of people seem to think that on RISE the Customer won't need a Basis Team, well, far from it, on RISE the Customer obviously won't need so many Basis people, but, and the big but is, the Customer will need exceptionally qualified and experienced Basis people who at the same time have a very good maturity and discipline in their behaviour. One of my biggest lessons, and there are many many learnings, has been, with RISE, due to the nature of the shared responsibilities, there is very little room for trial and error in the Basis Domain, and the Basis Team need to put massive effort in to proper planning and preparation of activities and understand who will do what bases upon the segregation of duties between SAP and the Customer. There is no room for trial and error when doing new things in the Basis area.

So, we could write a book about that, but we are here to share useful documentation, so here it comes...

RISE with SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition Security and Compliance

Sizing and Data Volume Management

In RISE, you have to take care of the System Sizing and Data Volume Management, SAP ECS deliver a T Shirt sized system and the rest is up to you, so here are some useful sizing related links...

As it says in this document, Principles of SAP HANA Sizing - on premise and cloud "Memory is the leading driver in (S/4) HANA sizing"...

And we need to go back to basics regarding HANA sizing and remember the 2 to 1 rule, which is also re-iterated here, 3307794 - How to judge if the available memory is sufficient for the current system - SAP for Me which points to item #10 of this Note 1999997 - FAQ: SAP HANA Memory - SAP for Me

The total size of column store and row store should not exceed 50 % of the allocation limit.

This next one is a very useful Sizing document for S/4HANA and S/4HANA Cloud, it's also useful for the PCE Edition, because it talks about Sizing S/4HANA for Non-SAP Systems which are calling API's on the S/4 and talks about how the S/4 Cloud QuickSizer has a category for API calls, and for some reason the PCE QuickSizer doesn't have that category. I find that more and more Non-SAP systems are calling OData API's on the S/4HANA and we need to be able to size for API calls, we need to think of a calling System as a User and the API as a Transaction and we need to understand the frequency of API calls, the complexity of the business logic behind the API call and the volume of the data being posted or gotten...

OData API's are extremely powerful compared to BAPI's and RFC's, and ODATA API's can even be executed as Batches and can execute very complex activities as I elaborated here https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blogs-by-members/s-4hana-odata-api-s-is-it-time-for-a-quot-safety-belt-quot/ba-p/13704550 I've seen OData API performance problems where the answer has been to create Indexes at the HANA level as is described here Multi-Column Index Types | SAP Help Portal and here CREATE INDEX Statement (Data Definition) | SAP Help Portal, and the point of the story, 

To Create Indexes at the HANA DB level, only the ECS Basis Team can do that and you will need a Service Request...

Regarding sizing S/4HANA for API calls from other and non-SAP systems, the recommendation I have is think of the calling System as a Standard User and the API as a Transaction and size it that way with the QuickSizer.

There are also however some interesting OSS Notes around the subject, for example this one for Success Factors, the Best Practices and Principles in this OSS Note, in my opinion, in general also apply in the case of S/4HANA

In the second quarter of 2025, SAP will announce an offering called “SAP ERP, private edition, transition option.” This cloud subscription service is designed to help large customers with complex installations on a RISE with SAP journey from SAP ERP systems to SAP cloud ERP.

In the meantime, there is this option....

RISE with SAP Limited Maintenance Policy 

The RISE LMP provides an overview of how SAP S/4HANA on-premise customers currently using a production system on a release not currently under mainstream maintenance or with less than nine months remaining of mainstream maintenance as of the start date of their Order Form for RISE with SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition or RISE with
SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition, tailored option (each a “RISE Private Edition”) can upgrade to a current SAP S/4HANA software release in mainstream maintenance through RISE Private Edition. Furthermore, the RISE LMP describes the process, technical framework, and associated pre-requisites for a customer to move and upgrade to RISE Private Edition from a release with limited or no remaining mainstream maintenance for SAP S/4HANA

Section 2] SAP ECS Enterprise Cloud Services

The SAP ECS Team is your Partner for pretty much everything, they are like your Cloud/Unix/Technical-Layer-Basis wrapped in to one, the majority of the really useful documentation on what the ECS Team do and how to work with them is listed below, but, you will need an S User and in some cases need to be a RISE Customer to access the documentation.

Section 3] Security on SAP RISE and ECS 

There is only one way to open the Security chapter of the 1 Pager and that is to begin with the....
